timeline.bodyText: Should we leave this generic? There is a risk this gets outdated when you add more metrics in the bridge + I guess already now it is missing JVM metrics?
timeline.author: scholzj

replies.bodyText: Yeah I forgot JVM as well, I will change with something more generic.
replies.author: ppatierno

timeline.bodyText: It is not clear from the PR what will be the context ... but the title Add Kafka Bridge sounds weird. Should it be just Kafka Bridge?
timeline.author: scholzj
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,11 @@
+// This assembly is included in the following assemblies:
+//
+// metrics/assembly-metrics.adoc
+
+[id='assembly-kafka-bridge-{context}']
+= Add Kafka Bridge

replies.bodyText: Yes agree, I was using the Kafka Exporter section as reference but it doesn't make sense "Add" here.
replies.author: ppatierno

replies.bodyText: To keep with the verb/object style of the other sub-headings in the chapter, maybe we can use Monitor Kafka Bridge instances
replies.author: PaulRMellor

timeline.bodyText: Do we really need this procedure? Would it be enough to just mention somewhere that you enable metrics by setting enableMetrics: true?
timeline.author: scholzj
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,53 @@
+// Module included in the following assemblies:
+//
+// metrics/assembly_metrics-kafka-bridge.adoc
+
+[id='proc-kafka-bridge-configuring-{context}']
+= Configuring Kafka Bridge

replies.bodyText: My though was following the Kafka Exporter documentation. We have a section for Kafka related metrics and for Kafka Exporter so I was thinking to add a related section for Kafka Bridge.
replies.author: ppatierno

replies.bodyText: Maybe we should mention the option in the using guide https://strimzi.io/docs/operators/master/using.html#assembly-deployment-configuration-kafka-bridge-str
replies.author: PaulRMellor

replies.bodyText: I don't mind it as a procedure. Readers get used to a certain format, it reassuring :-)  I think the next steps and ref to the schema is good too. Maybe we can trim it...
replies.author: PaulRMellor

replies.bodyText: I added a link to the assembly monitoring bridge from the bridge configuration section, in order to allow people to come here and see how to enable metrics for the bridge itself.
replies.author: ppatierno

timeline.bodyText: Similar to the above ... do we really need this procedure? Can't we just keep the list of items from the dashabord where you describe the location and remove this?
timeline.author: scholzj
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,51 @@

replies.bodyText: Same thought as before. Isn't it even enforced by PR #3269 with the refactoring made by Paul?
replies.author: ppatierno

timeline.bodyText: Document the default
timeline.author: tombentley

replies.bodyText: I had "... HTTP and Kafka metrics ..." there (I forgot JVM) but Jakub suggested being more generic in order to avoid that if adding more we had to change the description as well. Are you suggesting to revert back having something like "Enable the HTTP, Kafka, and JVM related metrics for the Kafka Bridge."?
replies.author: ppatierno

replies.bodyText: Does it default to true or false? I'm saying we should include what the default is in the @Description.
replies.author: tombentley

replies.bodyText: :-D I completely misunderstood what you meant! sorry! Yes it default to false, I will add it.
replies.author: ppatierno

timeline.bodyText: Maybe make the Kafka Bridge instances a link to the Kafka Bridge section and move the bullet section to the Kafka Bridge section introduction, as we're not setting up here.
timeline.author: PaulRMellor
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -7,12 +7,18 @@
 
 This section describes how to monitor Strimzi Kafka, ZooKeeper, Kafka Connect, and Kafka MirrorMaker and MirrorMaker 2.0 clusters using Prometheus to provide monitoring data for example Grafana dashboards.
 
-Prometheus and Grafana can also used to monitor Strimzi operators.
+Prometheus and Grafana can also be used to monitor Strimzi operators and Kafka Bridge instances.

timeline.author: PaulRMellor
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,53 @@
+// Module included in the following assemblies:
+//
+// metrics/assembly_metrics-kafka-bridge.adoc
+
+[id='proc-kafka-bridge-configuring-{context}']
+= Configuring Kafka Bridge
+
+This procedure shows how to enable Kafka Bridge metrics in the `KafkaBridge` resource.
+
+The property relevant to the Kafka Bridge configuration is shown in this procedure.
+
+You can configure this property as part of a deployment or redeployment of the Kafka Bridge.
+
+.Prerequisites
+
+* A Kubernetes cluster
+* A running Cluster Operator
+
+.Procedure
+
+. Edit the `spec.enableMetrics` property for the `KafkaBridge` resource.
++
+The property you can configure is shown in this example configuration:

timeline.bodyText: Step as link to https://strimzi.io/docs/operators/master/deploying.html#proc-metrics-grafana-dashboard-str
timeline.author: PaulRMellor
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,51 @@
+// Module included in the following assemblies:
+//
+// metrics/assembly_metrics-kafka-bridge.adoc
+
+[id='proc-kafka-bridge-enabling-{context}']
+
+= Enabling the Kafka Bridge Grafana dashboard
+
+If you deployed Kafka Bridge with your Kafka cluster, you can enable Grafana to present the metrics data it exposes.
+
+A Kafka Bridge dashboard is provided in the `examples/metrics` directory as a JSON file:
+
+* `strimzi-kafka-bridge.json`
+
+.Prerequisites
+
+* Kafka Bridge is deployed with xref:proc-kafka-bridge-configuring-{context}[Kafka Bridge metrics configuration]
+* xref:assembly-metrics-prometheus-{context}[Prometheus and Prometheus Alertmanager are deployed to the Kafka cluster]
+* xref:proc-metrics-deploying-grafana-{context}[Grafana is deployed to the Kafka cluster]
+
+This procedure assumes you already have access to the Grafana user interface and Prometheus has been added as a data source.
+If you are accessing the user interface for the first time, see xref:assembly-metrics-grafana-{context}[Grafana].
+
+.Procedure
+
+. Access the Grafana user interface.

replies.bodyText: I don't see it as a link in the Kafka Exporter section for example.
replies.author: ppatierno

timeline.bodyText:
Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
            . Click *Dashboards*, then *Import* to open the _Import Dashboard_ window and import the example Kafka Bridge dashboard (or paste the JSON).
          
          
            
            Select the _Kafka Bridge_ dashboard.
timeline.author: PaulRMellor
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,51 @@
+// Module included in the following assemblies:
+//
+// metrics/assembly_metrics-kafka-bridge.adoc
+
+[id='proc-kafka-bridge-enabling-{context}']
+
+= Enabling the Kafka Bridge Grafana dashboard
+
+If you deployed Kafka Bridge with your Kafka cluster, you can enable Grafana to present the metrics data it exposes.
+
+A Kafka Bridge dashboard is provided in the `examples/metrics` directory as a JSON file:
+
+* `strimzi-kafka-bridge.json`
+
+.Prerequisites
+
+* Kafka Bridge is deployed with xref:proc-kafka-bridge-configuring-{context}[Kafka Bridge metrics configuration]
+* xref:assembly-metrics-prometheus-{context}[Prometheus and Prometheus Alertmanager are deployed to the Kafka cluster]
+* xref:proc-metrics-deploying-grafana-{context}[Grafana is deployed to the Kafka cluster]
+
+This procedure assumes you already have access to the Grafana user interface and Prometheus has been added as a data source.
+If you are accessing the user interface for the first time, see xref:assembly-metrics-grafana-{context}[Grafana].
+
+.Procedure
+
+. Access the Grafana user interface.
+
+. Click *Dashboards*, then *Import* to open the _Import Dashboard_ window and import the example Kafka Bridge dashboard (or paste the JSON).

replies.bodyText: Why this change? In all the other places, I see the entire procedure to import a dashboard.
replies.author: ppatierno

timeline.bodyText:
Format should be like other dashboards:
Strimzi Kafka:: Shows metrics for:
+
* Brokers online count
* Active controllers in the cluster count
timeline.author: PaulRMellor
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,51 @@
+// Module included in the following assemblies:
+//
+// metrics/assembly_metrics-kafka-bridge.adoc
+
+[id='proc-kafka-bridge-enabling-{context}']
+
+= Enabling the Kafka Bridge Grafana dashboard
+
+If you deployed Kafka Bridge with your Kafka cluster, you can enable Grafana to present the metrics data it exposes.
+
+A Kafka Bridge dashboard is provided in the `examples/metrics` directory as a JSON file:
+
+* `strimzi-kafka-bridge.json`
+
+.Prerequisites
+
+* Kafka Bridge is deployed with xref:proc-kafka-bridge-configuring-{context}[Kafka Bridge metrics configuration]
+* xref:assembly-metrics-prometheus-{context}[Prometheus and Prometheus Alertmanager are deployed to the Kafka cluster]
+* xref:proc-metrics-deploying-grafana-{context}[Grafana is deployed to the Kafka cluster]
+
+This procedure assumes you already have access to the Grafana user interface and Prometheus has been added as a data source.
+If you are accessing the user interface for the first time, see xref:assembly-metrics-grafana-{context}[Grafana].
+
+.Procedure
+
+. Access the Grafana user interface.
+
+. Click *Dashboards*, then *Import* to open the _Import Dashboard_ window and import the example Kafka Bridge dashboard (or paste the JSON).
++
+When metrics data has been collected for some time, the Kafka Bridge charts are populated.
+
+.Kafka Bridge Grafana charts

@@ -0,0 +1,51 @@
+// Module included in the following assemblies:
+//
+// metrics/assembly_metrics-kafka-bridge.adoc
+
+[id='proc-kafka-bridge-enabling-{context}']
+
+= Enabling the Kafka Bridge Grafana dashboard
+
+If you deployed Kafka Bridge with your Kafka cluster, you can enable Grafana to present the metrics data it exposes.
+
+A Kafka Bridge dashboard is provided in the `examples/metrics` directory as a JSON file:
+
+* `strimzi-kafka-bridge.json`
+
+.Prerequisites
+
+* Kafka Bridge is deployed with xref:proc-kafka-bridge-configuring-{context}[Kafka Bridge metrics configuration]
+* xref:assembly-metrics-prometheus-{context}[Prometheus and Prometheus Alertmanager are deployed to the Kafka cluster]
+* xref:proc-metrics-deploying-grafana-{context}[Grafana is deployed to the Kafka cluster]
+
+This procedure assumes you already have access to the Grafana user interface and Prometheus has been added as a data source.
+If you are accessing the user interface for the first time, see xref:assembly-metrics-grafana-{context}[Grafana].
+
+.Procedure
+
+. Access the Grafana user interface.
+
+. Click *Dashboards*, then *Import* to open the _Import Dashboard_ window and import the example Kafka Bridge dashboard (or paste the JSON).
++
+When metrics data has been collected for some time, the Kafka Bridge charts are populated.
+
+.Kafka Bridge Grafana charts
+
+From the metrics, you can create charts to display:
+
+* The number of open HTTP connections to the bridge
+* Requests being processed

+// Module included in the following assemblies:
+//
+// metrics/assembly_metrics-kafka-bridge.adoc

+A Kafka Bridge dashboard is provided in the `examples/metrics` directory as a JSON file:

+* xref:assembly-metrics-prometheus-{context}[Prometheus and Prometheus Alertmanager are deployed to the Kafka cluster]

+This procedure assumes you already have access to the Grafana user interface and Prometheus has been added as a data source.

@@ -0,0 +1,51 @@
+// Module included in the following assemblies:
+//
+// metrics/assembly_metrics-kafka-bridge.adoc
+
+[id='proc-kafka-bridge-enabling-{context}']
+
+= Enabling the Kafka Bridge Grafana dashboard
+
+If you deployed Kafka Bridge with your Kafka cluster, you can enable Grafana to present the metrics data it exposes.
+
+A Kafka Bridge dashboard is provided in the `examples/metrics` directory as a JSON file:
+
+* `strimzi-kafka-bridge.json`
+
+.Prerequisites
+
+* Kafka Bridge is deployed with xref:proc-kafka-bridge-configuring-{context}[Kafka Bridge metrics configuration]
+* xref:assembly-metrics-prometheus-{context}[Prometheus and Prometheus Alertmanager are deployed to the Kafka cluster]
+* xref:proc-metrics-deploying-grafana-{context}[Grafana is deployed to the Kafka cluster]
+
+This procedure assumes you already have access to the Grafana user interface and Prometheus has been added as a data source.
+If you are accessing the user interface for the first time, see xref:assembly-metrics-grafana-{context}[Grafana].
+
+.Procedure
+
+. Access the Grafana user interface.
+
+. Click *Dashboards*, then *Import* to open the _Import Dashboard_ window and import the example Kafka Bridge dashboard (or paste the JSON).
++
+When metrics data has been collected for some time, the Kafka Bridge charts are populated.
+
+.Kafka Bridge Grafana charts
+
+From the metrics, you can create charts to display:
+
+* The number of open HTTP connections to the bridge
+* Requests being processed
+* Requests processed/secs grouped by HTTP method
+* The requests rate in total and even grouped by response codes (2XX, 4XX, 5XX)

+= Enabling the Kafka Bridge Grafana dashboard
+
+If you deployed Kafka Bridge with your Kafka cluster, you can enable Grafana to present the metrics data it exposes.
+
+A Kafka Bridge dashboard is provided in the `examples/metrics` directory as a JSON file:
+
+* `strimzi-kafka-bridge.json`
+
+.Prerequisites
+
+* Kafka Bridge is deployed with xref:proc-kafka-bridge-configuring-{context}[Kafka Bridge metrics configuration]
+* xref:assembly-metrics-prometheus-{context}[Prometheus and Prometheus Alertmanager are deployed to the Kafka cluster]
+* xref:proc-metrics-deploying-grafana-{context}[Grafana is deployed to the Kafka cluster]
+
+This procedure assumes you already have access to the Grafana user interface and Prometheus has been added as a data source.
+If you are accessing the user interface for the first time, see xref:assembly-metrics-grafana-{context}[Grafana].
+
+.Procedure
+
+. Access the Grafana user interface.
+
+. Click *Dashboards*, then *Import* to open the _Import Dashboard_ window and import the example Kafka Bridge dashboard (or paste the JSON).
++
+When metrics data has been collected for some time, the Kafka Bridge charts are populated.
+
+.Kafka Bridge Grafana charts
+
+From the metrics, you can create charts to display:
+
+* The number of open HTTP connections to the bridge
+* Requests being processed
+* Requests processed/secs grouped by HTTP method
+* The requests rate in total and even grouped by response codes (2XX, 4XX, 5XX)
+* Bytes received /sec and Bytes sent /sec
+* Requests for each bridge endpoint
+* Number of Kafka consumers, producers, and related opened connections used by the bridge itself
+* Kafka producer:
+** The average number of records sent per second (grouped by topic)
+** The number of outgoing bytes sent to all brokers per second (grouped by topic)
+** The average number of records per second that resulted in errors (grouped by topic)
+* Kafka consumer:
+** The average number of records consumed per second (grouped by clientId-topic)
+** The average number of bytes consumed per second (grouped by clientId-topic)
+** Partitions assigned (grouped by clientId)
+* JVM related metrics
